Reddi on Student Debt  "Student debt is the greatest challenge facing our current generation of graduates. Outstanding student debt reached $1.41 trillion in 2019. They are delaying marriage, homeownership and other major life decisions because of the stress from college loans. Meanwhile, private companies profit at their expense.  According to a report, nearly 60% of borrowers reported that their loan servicer has given them â€œconfusingâ€ or â€œunhelpfulâ€ advice about their loans. A quarter of the respondents had confronted a surprise additional fee from their servicing company, 57% had experienced unexpected demands after a sudden change in the loan servicer, and 42% had trouble negotiating a change to the repayment plan when they had financial hardships." See   We must support our young Kansas workforce and stand against attempts to undermine loan forgiveness programs. Our graduates must be able to attain a career without the burden of massive debt that forces them to choose between paying rent, buying food or defaulting on their loan. Today's generation has less buying power than my generation. We must remove Betsy Devos and call out predatory loan practices. This is on our watch!" - Usha Reddi  Donate Today!  Volunteer with us:

Reddi On Kansas Farming  A recent PBS NewsHour article says it well:   â€œRetaliation by China, Canada, Mexico, Turkey and members of the European Union to tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have taken a bite out of U.S. agricultural incomes. Tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum in the United States have also raised costs for machines, equipment and structures used by the agriculture sector.  â€œAgriculture incomes would have shown no growth in 2019 but for massive and unprecedented federal assistance.  â€œEven with this assistance, however, the agriculture sector shows signs of stress, with a rise in debt, a decrease in solvency and an increased number of bankruptcies."   See Article   Our farmers in Kansas and other states do not want subsidies. This is a temporary fix for a larger problem. Most farmers have lost so much that they will never be able to recover what they lost. Farmers should not be held hostage for political gain. Large corporations are profiting from the tariff and trade wars.   Donate today:  Volunteer:

Reddi on Renewable Energy and Climate Change  "The rumors and negativity concerning our renewable energy potential both as a state and as a nation are a result of direct misinformation campaigns by fossil fuel entities and their powerful political alliances on a global scale. The renewable energy potential of the state of Kansas is being neglected as a result of outside influence. Addressing the climate crisis means for Kansas a future where our economy flourishes and our environment is restored."  responsible energy sectors. There will always be damage done in the name of progress, but if we are not capable of addressing the issue of climate crisis now, there will be nothing left to progress."  U.S. Senate candidate Usha Reddi is not accepting any fossil fuel donations for her Senate campaign. Usha's campaign isn't up for sale, but it'll take your help to fight an election fossil fuel companies are trying to buy. Will you stand with her?  --> Donate Today!  --> Sign up to volunteer!

Reddi on Workforce  "We must capture the talent of our graduates and keep them in Kansas by providing quality jobs â€“ jobs that meet their needs and the needs of their families. Reddi on Statute of Limitations for Child Sexual Abuse  "I provided testimony in Topeka along with others to the House Committee on Judiciary regarding HB2306 which would extend the time that victims of child sex abuse have to bring a cause of action (a civil suit)."  "Currently, there is no statute of limitations to file criminal charges if you are a victim of child sexual abuse, but thatâ€™s not the same for civil suits. Let's be clear, there shouldn't be any statute of limitations on cases of sexual abuse, criminal or civil."  "As a survivor of childhood sexual abuse, I feel we should always work to remove barriers for victims of childhood sexual abuse. A Kansas Senator should be able to speak on behalf of all Kansans, especially the most vulnerable amongst us. My experiences are my own, but many Kansans will benefit from the passage of this legislation, and many more Americans will benefit if these stories are brought to the U.S. Senate floor."  Trigger warning: sexual assault and rape.  Listen to Usha's testimony and read the article:

Reddi on Healthcare  As a single mother of three, I remember having to do the math about which child should see a doctor or whether a problem was bad enough to see a doctor. As a teacher and elected official, Iâ€™ve seen and addressed the impact of healthcare insecurity on our Kansas communities.  The Affordable Care Act laid the groundwork for quality health care accessible to all. While Susan Wagle does everything she can to stop Medicaid expansion, and Roger Marshall believes some people â€œjust donâ€™t want health care,â€ I will be a staunch defender of the ACA and its provisions, particularly its protections for those with preexisting conditions, the provision to keep young people covered on their parentsâ€™ plans, and its protections for womenâ€™s reproductive rights.  Letâ€™s be clear, healthcare is a human right. Itâ€™s time to think bigger and consider an idea that builds on the ACA instead of going backwards by protecting insurance giants, pharmaceutical companies, and the lobbyists and lawyers they pay to influence legislation. I support Medicare for All because it addresses each of our current injustices. We can pay less for medication, cut middlemen out of the payment system, and finally focus the structures of health care on the patient. We can say goodbye to premiums, deductibles, and co-pays, and we can welcome a system that will take care of our people from infancy into their golden years.  We need insurance that encompasses dental care, vision, and womenâ€™s health care and treats substance abuse and mental illness, regardless of a patientâ€™s income, job, age or gender.

I'm With Reddi for Senate Rick Cagan, Former Executive Director of the National Alliance on Mental Health, Kansas "It is with much enthusiasm that I offer my personal endorsement for the candidacy of Usha Reddi for the U.S. Senate in 2020. Usha has been a friend and close colleague since 2015 given our shared interest in improving recovery opportunities for individuals living with mental illness and addiction and in providing needed support for individuals and family members affected by these health conditions."  "In our work through NAMI Kansas, Usha was quick to respond to the needs in our communities across the state for a stronger array of community-based services to avoid more costly alternatives such as hospitalization, incarceration and homelessness for individuals in crisis. In her home community in Riley County, she was an early supporter for the development of Crisis Intervention Teams and for establishing crisis services, which are now coming to fruition thanks in large measure to her persistence as a member of the City Commission and Mayor in Manhattan. In addition to serving with distinction on the NAMI Kansas Board of Directors, Usha has been an active participant in the Justice Involved Youth & Adults Subcommittee of the Governorâ€™s Behavioral Health Services Council." "I am proud to be on Ushaâ€™s team as she goes forward to seek the Democratic nomination for U.S. Senate. Reddi on Education  "As a teacher and a teachersâ€™ union leader, I've experienced the triumphs and challenges of our public education system. I believe we've all learned that as our public education goes, so goes the economy and our communities."  "I will give our teachers a seat at the policymaking table. If we want our education in Kansas to succeed, we have to give power to those who know public education best -- our teachers and educators."

Happy Kansas Day 2020! I've never been more proud to call Kansas, home. Meeting Kansans of every background is a constant reminder of why we entered the Union as a free state in 1861: Because our founders believed that every one of us deserves the chance to dream big and make our dreams real. Iâ€™m running for U.S. Senate because I believe Kansans are the kindest, toughest people Iâ€™ve ever met -- and our voices deserve to be heard. I believe America can learn from the decency that unite us, the work ethic that gets the job done, and the love for family that keep us all looking forward with hope. The photos we put together in this video say so much about the people across our state I've had the privilege to meet on this campaign. Letâ€™s honor our Kansas heritage by getting to know each other a little better! Happy Kansas Day. Hereâ€™s to a great 2020 for every one of us! #KansasDay #ReddiforSenate

After I was done speaking at the AFL-CIO KS state convention last week, I was pulled aside by someone who had a story to tell. Gary and his wife have worked their entire lives and appreciate the health insurance they have. But his wife of 25 years has dementia, and heâ€™s taking care of her now. He told me heâ€™s at a point where he needs a nursing assistant to help bathe her and he canâ€™t afford it because his insurance doesnâ€™t cover long-term needs. And his eyes started to well up with tears. When I bring up Medicare For All, I bring it up because people like Gary need it. Many Kansans are measuring the quality of their health care in sleepless nights, unaffordable bills, anxiety and tears. For Kansans, this isnâ€™t politics, this is personal. People all over our state see something in our campaign that theyâ€™re not seeing anywhere else. People like Gary are seeing a Senate candidate that speaks to them and their needs. What a week! We're officially less than a year away from the election, we're expanding our campaign team and we're ramping up our ground game across Kansas. I found time to make a trip out to Maryland to attend a dinner where I spoke with Maya Rockeymoore Cummings, wife of late Rep. Elijah Cummings. It was an inspiring night amongst inspiring people and it only encouraged us to fight harder for what we believe in and the progressive values that Kansans continually embrace and practice. â€Money is obviously an issue, as witnessed by a yearâ€™s worth of â€˜teachers canâ€™t live on a single teaching salaryâ€™ stories. But over the past couple of decades teachers have also suffered a steady drumbeat of disrespect, the repeated refrain that US schools are failing and terrible, an accountability movement that is more about threats than support.â€  As a teacher and local official, this offers painful validation. We can do better for our teachers and for the children and families they serve. There is no shortage of talent. Many teachers work 2 or 3 jobs outside of teaching to make ends meet.
